item.title: smtn
item.description:
One of the unsung heroes of my personal Linux server setups is a simple Node.js application I wrote called smtp-pushover. It’s an SMTP (email sending) server that forwards any email it receives to Pushover.

I recently rewrote it in Go and published the new version as smtn. It supports other notification services now!

item.title: A New Hugo Theme
item.description:
Oh hi, it’s been a while. What am I doing with this site again?

I don’t have a good answer for that right now. But maybe I’m getting a little closer to knowing.

I was recently reading some articles about the “small web” and it got me thinking about this site again. It inspired me to simplify it by writing my own theme. And of course, I made it all complicated again by bringing nix into another project.

item.title: Building Custom NixOS Images for the Raspberry Pi
item.description:
When installing NixOS on a computer, I’ve generally followed the same process:

  1. Boot NixOS installer
  2. Format and mount partitions
  3. Copy configuration.nix into place
  4. Run the installer
  5. Reboot

This works fine for most of my computers, but with a Raspberry Pi you don’t generally boot an installer off a USB stick. Instead, you install the operating system (like a Raspberry Pi OS image) directly to its SD card and boot that.

This is another place where NixOS shines. Let’s talk about building custom NixOS images for the Raspberry Pi.

item.title: Introducing Nappa and the Next Iteration of My k3s Cluster
item.description: It’s been almost two years since I built my first Raspberry Pi-powered k3s cluster. A lot’s changed! There’s a new node in the cluster and I’ve gone off the deep end switching everything to NixOS. In this post, I’ll talk about the new node and some of the nix options that enable it.

item.title: Installing Nix and Home Manager in Arch Linux
item.description:
Hi, I’m Matt and I’m one of those masochists who uses a chromebook as their personal development machine (not work though, I’m not that crazy). A cool thing about Chrome OS’s Linux support is that you can swap the default, boring Debian container for any LXC image. Here’s an archwiki page on how to swap it to Arch!

A not-so-cool thing about that LXC setup is that there isn’t a NixOS LXC image available ðŸ˜¢. Instead, I set up an Arch Linux container with Nix and Home Manager. Best of both worlds I guess? Here’s how to do it.

item.title: Getting Dependabot and semantic-release to Play Nice
item.description:
The other day, GitHub sent me a notification that there were a couple security vulnerabilities in the dependencies of one of my personal projects, castaway. Having used Dependabot at work, I figured I’d enable it and get that vulnerability taken care of.

After I merged one of Dependabot’s PRs, I was shocked (ðŸ˜±) to find that semantic-release hadn’t made a release for it. Dependabot prefixed the commit with build(deps):, and semantic-release only creates releases for commits with prefixes fix and feat.

What’s the point of a security update if it doesn’t actually build a new image? Looks like I’ve got some work to do.

item.title: Removing Old Torrents Using a Raspberry Pi Cluster
item.description:
My new Raspberry Pi cluster is a little unstable and pretty limited since the nodes have just 1GB of memory. What the heck could I possibly use this for?

Turns out it’s great at running simple cron jobs. In this case, one that cleans up old torrents on a remote qbittorrent server.

item.title: Saibamen Attack! Building a Raspberry Pi Cluster
item.description:
Over the holidays I made a k3s (that’s Kubernetes minus 5) cluster out of Raspberry Pis I had lying around. And while it’s extremely cool, it’s also pretty unstable.

In this post, I’ll outline what this new cluster looks like and go into detail on how I set it up. At the end, I’ll talk a little bit about why I won’t be entrusting it with my most important tasks just yet.

item.title: Switching to Hugo
item.description:
Welp, I switched this website from Gatsby to Hugo.

This reminds me of my distro-hoppin’ days, when I used to spend nights installing different Linux distributions and then meticulously configuring them to my liking. “Oh man, I can get so much done with this distro!”, I’d say. I spent so mush time trying to find that perfect setup, that I didn’t spend much time actually using them to get things done.

Well, I guess I haven’t changed much. After writing a single post, I decided to try something else for this website. Let’s at least talk about the notable changes in a second post…
